options.D: Remote wipe can only be done locally while connected to Wi-Fi, while remote backup works over any network connection

explanation: A remote wipe sends a command to the mobile device to erase all data, returning it to factory settings. This is used when a device is lost or stolen to prevent unauthorized access to sensitive data. A remote backup saves the device data (contacts, photos, app data, settings) to a cloud service or corporate server so it can be restored to a new device. Ideally, regular remote backups should be performed so that data can be recovered after a remote wipe is executed.

question: A company's mobile security policy specifies that after 10 failed login attempts, the device should automatically erase all data. What is the purpose of this policy?

options.A: To save battery life on the device by clearing memory and reducing background processes after failed attempts
options.B: To protect sensitive data from brute-force attacks by wiping the device if someone repeatedly tries to guess the passcode
options.C: To free up storage space on the device by removing cached data and temporary files after failed login attempts
options.D: To force users to remember their passwords by penalizing them for too many incorrect authentication attempts

explanation: A failed login attempt policy that triggers a device wipe after a specified number of failures (e.g., 10 attempts) protects against brute-force attacks on the device passcode. If someone attempts to guess the passcode by trying many combinations, the device will automatically erase all data after the threshold is reached, preventing unauthorized access to sensitive corporate data. This policy is typically enforced through MDM and is an important mobile security measure.

question: Why is full-device encryption important for mobile device security?

options.A: It makes the device run faster by optimizing storage read and write operations through hardware acceleration
options.B: It ensures all stored data is encrypted and unreadable without proper authentication, protecting data if the device is lost
options.C: It prevents the device from connecting to wireless networks by encrypting the network adapter configuration settings
options.D: It doubles the device's storage capacity through compression that is applied transparently during the encryption

explanation: Full-device encryption encrypts all data stored on the mobile device so that it cannot be read without the proper decryption key (tied to the user's passcode/biometric). This is critical because mobile devices are easily lost or stolen. Without encryption, an attacker could remove the storage chip or bypass the lock screen to access the data. Modern iOS devices encrypt by default when a passcode is set, and Android devices support full-disk or file-based encryption.

question: How do corporate-owned mobile device policies differ from BYOD policies?

options.A: There is no difference in how corporate-owned and BYOD devices are managed; both follow identical policies and MDM controls
options.B: Corporate-owned devices allow full organizational control (including wipe and app restrictions), while BYOD balances security with privacy via containerization
options.C: BYOD devices are always more secure than corporate-owned devices because employees keep their personal device software updated
options.D: Corporate-owned devices cannot be managed by MDM solutions and require manual individual configuration on each separate device

explanation: Corporate-owned devices give the organization full control: they can enforce all security policies, install/remove any apps, fully wipe the device, and monitor all activity. BYOD policies must balance organizational security needs with employee privacy rights since the device belongs to the employee. BYOD typically uses containerization (separating work data from personal data) so the organization can manage and wipe corporate data without affecting personal data. MDM manages both types but with different levels of control.

question: A user's mobile device is configured with a locator app but the device has been offline for 24 hours after being lost. What can still be done through MDM?

options.A: Nothing can be done; MDM cannot affect an offline device that is not connected to any network or cellular service
options.B: Queue a remote wipe command that will execute when the device reconnects, and change the user's cloud account passwords
options.C: Physically track the device using Bluetooth even when offline by triangulating signals from nearby paired devices
options.D: Remotely charge the device battery using wireless charging technology to bring the device back online for tracking

explanation: Even when a device is offline, MDM can queue a remote wipe command that will execute as soon as the device reconnects to the internet (via Wi-Fi or cellular). Additionally, the IT department should immediately change the user's cloud account passwords (email, corporate apps) to prevent anyone from accessing corporate data through those accounts from any device. Some devices also support offline Bluetooth-based finding networks, but the remote wipe queue is the primary security measure.

question: Which physical data destruction method uses a strong magnetic field to erase data from magnetic storage media?

options.A: Shredding
options.B: Degaussing
options.C: Drilling
options.D: Incineration

explanation: Degaussing uses a powerful magnetic field to erase data on magnetic storage media (hard drives, tapes) by randomizing the magnetic domains, making the data unrecoverable. Degaussing is effective for magnetic media but does NOT work on SSDs or flash storage (which use electrical charges, not magnetism). Shredding physically destroys the media into small pieces, drilling creates holes through the platters, and incineration burns the media.

question: What is the difference between a standard format and a low-level format for data sanitization?

options.A: They are identical processes that produce the same result when erasing data from any type of storage media or drive
options.B: A standard format removes file system references but data may be recoverable, while a low-level format overwrites every sector on the drive
options.C: A low-level format is faster than a standard format because it skips the verification step after writing to each sector
options.D: A standard format is more secure than a low-level format for sanitizing sensitive data on magnetic and solid-state drives

explanation: A standard (quick) format only removes the file system metadata (directory structure, file allocation table) but leaves the actual data on the disk, making it potentially recoverable with data recovery tools. A low-level format (or full format with overwrite) writes to every sector of the disk, overwriting existing data and making recovery extremely difficult or impossible. For secure data sanitization, a low-level format or dedicated disk wiping tool with multiple overwrite passes is recommended.

question: A healthcare organization needs to dispose of old hard drives that contained patient records (HIPAA-regulated data). Which approach ensures compliance?

options.A: Simply delete all files from the drives, empty the recycle bin, and recycle the hardware for reuse
options.B: Physically destroy the drives (shredding or degaussing) and obtain a certificate of destruction from a certified vendor
options.C: Format the drives with a quick format using the built-in OS tools and then donate them for reuse
options.D: Store the drives in a secure closet indefinitely without performing any data destruction procedures

explanation: HIPAA and other regulations require that protected data be destroyed in a manner that ensures it cannot be recovered. Physical destruction (shredding, degaussing, or incineration) with a certificate of destruction from a certified third-party vendor provides verifiable proof of compliant data destruction. Simple file deletion or quick formatting is not sufficient as data can be recovered. Indefinite storage creates ongoing security liability. The certificate of destruction is important for regulatory audits.

question: Why is it important to consider environmental regulations when disposing of electronic equipment and storage media?

options.A: Environmental regulations only apply to paper documents and do not cover electronic equipment or storage media
options.B: Electronics contain hazardous materials (lead, mercury, cadmium) that must be disposed of properly to comply with e-waste regulations
options.C: Environmental regulations do not apply to data storage devices and only cover large industrial electronic equipment
options.D: All electronic equipment can be safely disposed of in regular trash because modern devices contain no hazardous materials

explanation: Electronic equipment and storage media contain hazardous materials including lead, mercury, cadmium, and other toxic substances that can contaminate soil and water if improperly disposed of. Environmental regulations (such as WEEE in Europe and various state e-waste laws) require proper recycling or disposal through certified e-waste facilities. Organizations must balance data security (ensuring data is destroyed) with environmental responsibility (ensuring proper disposal of physical materials).

question: When should physical destruction be chosen over software-based data erasure for drive sanitization?

options.A: Physical destruction is never necessary; software erasure is always sufficient for all data sensitivity levels and compliance requirements
options.B: Physical destruction should be used for highly sensitive data, regulatory compliance, damaged drives, or when the highest assurance is needed
options.C: Software-based erasure should never be used because it cannot reliably remove data from any modern storage device
options.D: Physical destruction is only used for floppy disks and other legacy storage media that cannot be erased with software

explanation: Physical destruction (shredding, degaussing, drilling, incineration) provides the highest level of assurance that data cannot be recovered and should be chosen for: highly classified or sensitive data, regulatory requirements that mandate physical destruction, drives that are damaged or malfunctioning (where software tools cannot access all sectors), and situations requiring absolute certainty of data elimination. Software-based erasure is acceptable for less sensitive data and when drives will be reused.

question: A company is outsourcing its data destruction to a third-party vendor. What documentation should the company require?

options.A: No documentation is needed when outsourcing data destruction to a third-party vendor with a service agreement
options.B: A certificate of destruction including serial numbers, destruction method, date, and the vendor's certification credentials
options.C: Only a verbal confirmation that the drives were destroyed is needed from the vendor representative on site
options.D: A receipt showing the drives were received by the vendor for processing is the only documentation required

explanation: When outsourcing data destruction, the company should require a certificate of destruction that documents: serial numbers of all destroyed devices (creating an audit trail), the destruction method used (shredding, degaussing, etc.), the date of destruction, and the vendor's certifications (such as NAID AAA certification). This documentation is essential for regulatory compliance, audit trails, and legal protection. A receipt alone does not verify that destruction actually occurred.

question: Which data destruction method is effective for solid-state drives (SSDs) but NOT for traditional magnetic hard drives specifically?

options.A: Degaussing
options.B: Incineration
options.C: Cryptographic erasure
options.D: Shredding

explanation: Cryptographic erasure involves erasing the encryption key for a self-encrypting drive, rendering all encrypted data on the drive permanently unreadable. This is particularly effective for SSDs because traditional overwrite methods may not reach all cells due to wear-leveling and over-provisioning. Degaussing does NOT work on SSDs (which do not use magnetism). Incineration and shredding physically destroy both types but the drive cannot be reused. Cryptographic erasure allows the SSD to be securely sanitized and reused.

question: What is the purpose of drilling holes through a hard drive as a data destruction method?

options.A: To improve airflow and cooling for the drive by creating ventilation holes in the sealed enclosure
options.B: To physically damage the platters so data on destroyed areas cannot be recovered with standard equipment
options.C: To create ventilation holes for safe storage of decommissioned drives in a server room storage cabinet
options.D: To attach the drive to a mounting bracket by providing anchor points for screws and fasteners

explanation: Drilling holes through a hard drive physically damages the magnetic platters, destroying the data stored in the drilled areas and warping surrounding areas. The physical damage also prevents the drive from being used in standard equipment. While drilling does not destroy all data on the platters (undamaged areas may still be readable by specialized forensic labs), it provides a reasonable level of destruction for most purposes. For the highest security, shredding or incineration is preferred.

question: What is the FIRST thing that should be changed when setting up a new SOHO wireless router?

options.A: The Wi-Fi channel to avoid interference from neighboring networks
options.B: The default administrator username and password for security
options.C: The SSID broadcast setting to hide the network from scanning
options.D: The antenna position to optimize the wireless signal coverage

explanation: The first and most critical security step when setting up a new SOHO router is to change the default administrator username and password. Default credentials are publicly known and documented online for virtually every router model. If left unchanged, anyone on the network (or with physical access) can log into the router's administration interface and modify all settings, disable security features, or redirect traffic. This is a fundamental SOHO network security measure.

question: A small business wants to allow customers to use Wi-Fi for internet access without giving them access to the internal business network where point-of-sale systems and file servers reside. What should be configured?

options.A: Give customers the main network password and ask them not to access internal business resources
options.B: Set up a separate guest wireless network that is isolated from the internal business network
options.C: Disable wireless encryption so customers can connect easily without needing a password to join
options.D: Turn off the router when customers are not present and enable it during business hours only

explanation: A guest wireless network creates a separate, isolated network segment for visitors that provides internet access but blocks access to the internal business network resources (servers, printers, POS systems). Most modern SOHO routers support guest network functionality. The guest network should use its own password and WPA2/WPA3 encryption. This prevents customers from accessing sensitive business resources while providing the convenience of Wi-Fi access.

question: Why should UPnP (Universal Plug and Play) be disabled on a SOHO router for security purposes?

options.A: UPnP uses too much bandwidth and degrades network performance for all connected devices on the router
options.B: UPnP automatically opens ports on the router firewall for applications, which malware can exploit to create backdoors
options.C: UPnP prevents devices from connecting to the network by blocking incoming connections at the firewall level
options.D: UPnP is only needed for enterprise networks and has no functionality on consumer SOHO router hardware

explanation: UPnP (Universal Plug and Play) allows devices and applications on the network to automatically configure port forwarding rules on the router without user intervention. While convenient, this creates a security risk because malware or unauthorized applications can use UPnP to open ports and create backdoors through the firewall without the user's knowledge. Disabling UPnP forces manual port forwarding configuration, giving the administrator full control over which ports are open.

question: What is the difference between disabling SSID broadcast and using wireless encryption for network security?

options.A: Disabling SSID broadcast provides strong security that protects data, while encryption does not offer meaningful protection
options.B: Disabling SSID broadcast hides the network name but is easily discovered with tools; encryption protects data by making it unreadable without the key
options.C: Encryption hides the network name from scanning tools, while SSID broadcast settings protect data transmitted over the network
options.D: Both disabling SSID broadcast and enabling encryption provide identical and equivalent levels of wireless security protection

explanation: Disabling SSID broadcast hides the network name from appearing in standard Wi-Fi network lists, but the SSID can still be easily discovered using wireless scanning tools (since it is transmitted in probe responses and association frames). It provides minimal security through obscurity. Wireless encryption (WPA2/WPA3 with AES) actually protects data by encrypting all wireless traffic, making it unreadable without the correct key. Encryption is the essential security measure; hiding the SSID is optional and adds minimal security.

question: A SOHO router has not had its firmware updated in two years. Why is this a security concern, and what should be done?

options.A: Firmware updates only change the router's user interface appearance and have no impact on security or performance
options.B: Outdated firmware may contain known security vulnerabilities patched in newer versions; update to the latest firmware from the manufacturer
options.C: Firmware should never be updated on SOHO routers because updates may break the device's configuration and connectivity
options.D: Firmware updates only apply to enterprise-grade routers and are not available or necessary for SOHO router devices

explanation: Router firmware updates frequently include patches for security vulnerabilities that have been discovered since the previous version. Running outdated firmware leaves the router exposed to known exploits that attackers can use to gain control of the router, redirect traffic, intercept data, or use the router as part of a botnet. The firmware should be updated to the latest version from the manufacturer's official website. Regular firmware update checks should be part of ongoing network maintenance.

question: What is a screened subnet (DMZ) in SOHO network security?

options.A: A subnet that has been disconnected from the internet and can only communicate with devices on the local network
options.B: A network segment between the external and internal networks that hosts public services while protecting the internal network
options.C: A subnet that only allows wireless connections and blocks all wired Ethernet traffic for security and isolation
options.D: A backup network used when the primary network fails, providing automatic failover for business continuity

explanation: A screened subnet (commonly called a DMZ or demilitarized zone) is a network segment positioned between the external (internet-facing) and internal (private) networks. It hosts services that need to be accessible from the internet (web servers, email servers, VPN endpoints) while keeping the internal network protected. Traffic from the internet can reach the DMZ but cannot directly access the internal network. Many SOHO routers offer a basic DMZ feature.

question: A user needs to access a security camera from outside their home network. The camera uses port 8080. What should be configured on the SOHO router?

options.A: Disable the firewall completely to allow all inbound traffic to reach devices on the network
options.B: Configure port forwarding to forward external port 8080 to the camera's internal IP and port
options.C: Enable UPnP and let it automatically configure port mappings without manual intervention
options.D: Change the router's SSID to include the camera's IP address for identification purposes

explanation: Port forwarding should be configured on the router to direct incoming traffic on port 8080 from the internet to the internal IP address of the security camera. This allows external access to the camera while keeping the firewall active for all other ports. Disabling the firewall would expose all internal devices. UPnP is a security risk. For better security, consider using a VPN to access the camera instead of direct port forwarding.

question: What does content filtering on a SOHO router do?

options.A: Filters dust and debris from the router's internal components to maintain optimal hardware performance
options.B: Blocks access to specific websites, content categories, or keywords to restrict inappropriate or dangerous content
options.C: Filters email messages for spam and phishing attempts before they reach the recipient's inbox
options.D: Compresses web content to reduce bandwidth usage and improve page loading speeds for all users

explanation: Content filtering on a SOHO router blocks access to specific websites, website categories (adult content, gambling, social media), or pages containing specific keywords. This is useful for parental controls, workplace productivity, and security (blocking known malicious sites). Content filtering can be configured on the router itself (some models have built-in features) or by using third-party DNS-based content filtering services like OpenDNS.

question: Why should unused ports on a SOHO router's firewall be closed or blocked?

options.A: Open ports improve network performance by allowing more traffic throughput on the router
options.B: Each open port is a potential entry point for attackers; closing unused ports reduces the attack surface
options.C: Closing ports prevents the router from overheating by reducing the processing load on the device
options.D: Unused ports cannot be exploited by attackers, so it does not matter whether they are open or closed

explanation: Every open port on a firewall represents a potential entry point that attackers can use to gain unauthorized access to the network. Open ports may have vulnerable services listening on them that can be exploited. By closing (blocking) all unused ports and only opening ports that are specifically needed for required services, the attack surface is minimized. This follows the principle of least privilege applied to network access. Regular port audits help ensure only necessary ports remain open.

question: What is the difference between IP filtering and MAC filtering on a SOHO router?

options.A: They are the same feature with different names; both filter traffic using identical network identification methods
options.B: IP filtering allows or blocks traffic based on IP addresses, while MAC filtering controls access based on hardware addresses; MAC is easier to spoof
options.C: MAC filtering is more secure than IP filtering in all cases because hardware addresses are permanently assigned to devices
options.D: IP filtering works on wireless networks only, while MAC filtering is exclusively used on wired Ethernet network connections

explanation: IP filtering controls network access by allowing or blocking traffic based on source or destination IP addresses. MAC filtering controls access by allowing or blocking devices based on their physical hardware (MAC) addresses. While MAC filtering adds a layer of access control, it is relatively easy to bypass because MAC addresses can be spoofed (changed) using software. Both can be used together as part of a defense-in-depth strategy, but neither should be relied upon as the sole security measure.

question: Why is it important to only download software and browser extensions from trusted sources?

options.A: Software from untrusted sources always runs slower due to lack of optimization and code signing
options.B: Untrusted sources may distribute software bundled with malware, spyware, adware, or other malicious code
options.C: Trusted sources provide free software, while untrusted sources always charge money for their downloads
options.D: There is no difference between trusted and untrusted software sources; both are equally safe to use

explanation: Software and browser extensions from untrusted sources may contain malware, spyware, adware, or other malicious code hidden within the download. Trusted sources (official websites, verified app stores, reputable repositories) have review processes and security checks that reduce the risk of downloading malicious software. Even from trusted sources, verifying the download hash can ensure the file has not been tampered with during download.

question: What is the purpose of verifying a file's hash value after downloading it?

options.A: To check if the downloaded file will be compatible with the operating system and installed hardware drivers
options.B: To verify the integrity of the download by confirming the file has not been altered, corrupted, or tampered with
options.C: To encrypt the downloaded file for security before opening or executing it on the local system
options.D: To compress the file to save disk space by reducing its size before installation or extraction

explanation: A hash value (MD5, SHA-256, etc.) is a unique fingerprint generated from a file's contents. Software publishers provide the expected hash alongside their downloads. After downloading, computing the file's hash and comparing it to the published hash verifies that the file was not corrupted during transfer, tampered with by an attacker, or replaced with a malicious version. If the hashes match, the file is identical to the original. Any modification, even one byte, produces a completely different hash.

question: A user's browser displays a warning that a website's security certificate is expired or invalid. What does this mean and what should the user do?

options.A: The warning is just informational and can be safely ignored; it does not indicate any real security risk to the user
options.B: The SSL/TLS certificate has expired, been revoked, or doesn't match the domain; the connection may not be secure so do not proceed
options.C: The user's browser is out of date and needs to be updated to the latest version from the vendor to resolve this warning
options.D: The website is loading too slowly and should be refreshed or accessed again after clearing the browser cache data

explanation: Certificate warnings indicate that the SSL/TLS certificate used to encrypt the connection is expired, revoked, self-signed, or does not match the website's domain name. This could mean the certificate was simply not renewed (less dangerous but still a concern) or that an attacker is intercepting the connection with a fraudulent certificate (very dangerous). Users should not bypass these warnings, especially for banking, email, or any site requiring login credentials or sensitive information.

question: What is the difference between a browser's private/incognito mode and using a VPN?

options.A: They provide identical privacy protections and can be used interchangeably for the same overall level of online security
options.B: Private mode prevents local browser history and cookie saving but doesn't hide network activity; a VPN encrypts traffic and hides it from the ISP
options.C: VPN only prevents local history saving on the device, while private mode encrypts all network traffic and hides the user's activity
options.D: Private mode is more secure than a VPN for all purposes because it prevents all forms of online tracking and monitoring

explanation: Private/incognito mode only affects the local browser: it prevents saving browsing history, cookies, form data, and cached files on the device after the session ends. However, the ISP, network administrator, and websites can still see your activity. A VPN encrypts all network traffic between your device and the VPN server, hiding your browsing activity from the local network, ISP, and potential eavesdroppers. For complete privacy, both can be used together.

question: Why is it important to keep web browsers updated with the latest patches?

options.A: Updates only change the browser's visual appearance and user interface without any security improvements
options.B: Browser updates patch security vulnerabilities that attackers could exploit to steal data or install malware through malicious websites
options.C: Browser updates are optional and never contain security fixes; they only add new features and interface changes
options.D: Outdated browsers run faster than updated ones because newer versions include more resource-intensive features

explanation: Web browsers are a primary attack vector because they process complex content from the internet, including HTML, JavaScript, images, and plugins. Security vulnerabilities in browsers can be exploited by malicious websites to execute arbitrary code, steal credentials, install malware, or compromise the system. Regular browser updates patch these vulnerabilities. Browser vendors regularly release security patches, and keeping the browser current is one of the most important security practices for end users.

question: A user has installed numerous browser extensions, and the browser has become slow and displays unexpected pop-up advertisements. What should the technician recommend?

options.A: Install additional extensions to block the ads from other extensions and improve browser performance
options.B: Review and remove unnecessary or suspicious browser extensions, as some may be malicious or contain adware
options.C: Reinstall the operating system to fix the browser issues caused by incompatible extension configurations
options.D: Increase the computer's RAM to handle the extensions and reduce the slowness caused by memory pressure

explanation: Browser extensions have significant access to browser data and web activity. Malicious or poorly coded extensions can inject advertisements, track browsing activity, steal credentials, slow performance, and redirect searches. The technician should review all installed extensions, remove any that are unnecessary, suspicious, or from untrusted sources, and verify that remaining extensions are from reputable developers with good reviews. Only essential, trusted extensions should be kept installed.

question: What is the benefit of using a browser-integrated or third-party password manager?

options.A: Password managers make passwords easier to share with coworkers by storing them in a shared accessible vault
options.B: Password managers generate and store unique, complex passwords for each account, eliminating password reuse
options.C: Password managers store passwords in plain text for easy access without any encryption or security measures
options.D: Password managers eliminate the need for any form of authentication by automatically logging users in

explanation: Password managers securely generate, store, and auto-fill unique, complex passwords for each website and account. This eliminates the need to remember multiple passwords and prevents the common security risk of password reuse (using the same password across multiple sites). If one site is breached, only that unique password is compromised. Password managers encrypt their password vaults with a master password and often support multi-factor authentication for additional security.

question: A company wants to prevent employees from accessing social media and streaming sites during work hours through their web browsers. Which browser or network-level configuration would help?

options.A: Enable private browsing mode on all browsers to prevent employees from being tracked online
options.B: Configure a proxy server or secure DNS with content filtering to block specific website categories
options.C: Uninstall the web browser from all workstations to prevent any internet access during work hours
options.D: Change the desktop wallpaper to a reminder about company policy on acceptable internet usage

explanation: A proxy server or secure DNS with content filtering can block access to specific website categories (social media, streaming, gaming) across all browsers on the network. This can be configured at the browser level (proxy settings), at the network level (DNS-based filtering like OpenDNS), or through Group Policy in a domain environment. Private browsing only hides local history and does not prevent access. Removing browsers is impractical if web access is needed for work.

question: What is the purpose of clearing browsing data and cache in a web browser?

options.A: To increase the browser's maximum download speed by removing cached data that slows connection handling
options.B: To remove stored temporary files, cookies, cached pages, and browsing history that could contain sensitive information
options.C: To uninstall the browser completely from the system and remove all associated application data files
options.D: To update the browser to the latest version by clearing old files that prevent the update from installing

explanation: Clearing browsing data removes temporary files, cookies (which may contain session data or tracking information), cached web pages, browsing history, saved form data, and download history. This is important for privacy (removing traces of browsing activity), security (clearing stored credentials and session cookies), and troubleshooting (resolving website display issues caused by corrupted or outdated cached content). It is especially important on shared or public computers.

question: What is the difference between a pop-up blocker and an ad blocker in a web browser?

options.A: They are identical in function; both block the same types of unwanted content in the browser
options.B: A pop-up blocker prevents new windows or tabs from opening automatically, while an ad blocker hides embedded advertisements
options.C: Ad blockers only work on mobile browsers, while pop-up blockers work exclusively on desktop browser platforms
options.D: Pop-up blockers remove all images from web pages, while ad blockers only block text-based advertisements

explanation: Pop-up blockers prevent websites from automatically opening new browser windows or tabs (pop-ups), which are often used for advertising or malicious purposes. Most browsers include a built-in pop-up blocker. Ad blockers (typically browser extensions like uBlock Origin) go further by removing or hiding advertisements embedded within web pages, including banner ads, video ads, and tracking scripts. Both improve browsing security and experience, but ad blockers provide more comprehensive content filtering.
